page.title: 01Inchmickery - description
page.content:
Inchmickery is a most unattractive island with decaying concrete from the First (1914 - 1918) and Second (1939 - 1945) World Wars.
The land area is about 3 acres, low lying and is part of Lothian Region belonging to the parish of Cramond.
To the north lies a 5 fathom channel channel with a centre 10 fathom deep hole sheltered by the Cow & Calves island. To the south the water is 5 fathoms deep with sand banks and quicksand patches towards Cramond and the estuarine mud flats at the mouth of the River Almond.
The Inch of the name is Innis or Ennis which is Celtic for island. Access to the island is by permit from the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds.
